basics.name: John Yamamoto
basics.label: Student
basics.summary: I am studying for a B.A. in Computer Science in the Department of Information and Computer Sciences at the University of Hawaii. I expect to graduate in Spring, 2027.

work.summary: Working in the summers for the company's helpdesk, handling small hardware projects for the company, and studying and practicing computer networking.
highlights: Consistently provided clients with fast, detailed, and quality help with hardware, applications, and account management and creation.
Diligently worked with IT team to complete large-scale e-waste and VoIP switchover projects for the company

volunteer.summary: Served homeless people on the street and at RYSE.
highlights: Led teams of friends to serve pizza and cold sodas to homeless people in Oahu's downtown area.
Served meals and spent time with homeless youth at RYSE.
Served on a team that provides food, showers, and clothing to Waikiki's homeless population.

volunteer.organization: Hawaii Baptist Academy National Honor Society
volunteer.position: St. Francis/Food Delivery Committee Co-Chair and Hope for the Homeless Committee Member
volunteer.summary: Led and served in projects involving St. Francis hospital, The Pantry Food Shelter, and HBA faculty.
highlights: Formed and maintained a healthy partnership with the Administrative Secretary of St. Francis Hospital while successfully organizing and leading teams of student volunteers at St. Francis Hospital throughout the of the 2020-2021 school year as Co-Chair of the St. Francis committee.
Organized teams of volunteers to work at a homeless feeding non-profit organization called The Pantry over the spring break of the 2021-2022 semester as Co-Chair of the Food Delivery committee.

awards.title: Academic Merit Scholarship
awards.summary: Hawaiâ€™i residents with a high school cumulative GPA of 3.6 or higher will be considered for a $4,000 scholarship per year.

awards.title: AP Scholar Award
awards.summary: The AP Scholar awards are given by the College Board to students who have achieved high scores on multiple Advanced Placement (AP) exams.
